Thanks, Darcy.  I tend to like old iron mumei examples, and I only got interested in tsuba recently, so I don't own the kind Sasano did.  Maybe I should get a sword polished, and try papering it.  

 

----- Original Message ----- 
  From: samurai@... 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, March 20, 2005 4:34 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba



  Hi David,

  I have not submitted many (any) tsuba, but was faced with the same
  dilemma. 

  I would think:

  1. if there is a possibility that it is old and rare vs. the more common
     pieces and you want to assure yourself or a buyer of this

  2. it has a big name and you want assurance it is legit

  3. it's going to paper high

  Otherwise, papers cover a substantial portion of the price of a tsuba if
  papered... I'd say generally avoid it as not being fiscally sound.

  That said I think the NTHK has much better prices on papering tsuba that
  make more sense than the NBTHK. I was considering NTHK papers for mine.

  - darcy
     
  <jdz@...> writes:

  > I've never submitted anything for papers, and just to experience the process I was thinking of submitting one or two tsuba to shinsa.  

  > But looking at the costs, and not believing I own any more than Hozon-level sorts of tsuba, I began to wonder if it made sense to spend several hundred dollars just to add minimum Hozon papers, or perhaps to fail.  

  > Any wisdom out there on how good a tsuba needs to be to be Hozon or Tokubetsu Hozon?  Why paper a tsuba at all?  What makes you decide to submit a particular one?

  > DZ
